questions.question: Who built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people)?
questions.explaination: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people). Included in the wall were a number of forts. Parts of Hadrian’s Wall, including the forts of Housesteads and Vindolanda, can still be seen.

questions.question: When was the Domesday Book written?
questions.explaination: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

questions.question: When were the first coins in Britain made?
questions.explaination: The people of the Iron Age had a sophisticated culture and economy. They made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings.

questions.answer: The names of Iron Age kings
questions.question: What was inscribed in the first coins to be minted in Britain during the Iron Age?
options: The names of Iron Age Gods
The names of Iron Age kings
The names of Iron Age fighters
The names of Iron Age flowers
questions.explaination: The people of the Iron Age had a sophisticated culture and economy. They made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings. This marks the beginnings of British history.

questions.question: Boudicca, was a tribal leader who fought against which foreign invaders?
questions.explaination: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

questions.question: Who defeated the Vikings?
questions.explaination: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

questions.question: Which of the following monuments is located in Wiltshire?
questions.explaination: One of these monuments, Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies.

questions.question: Who was the first Archbishop of Canterbury?
questions.explaination: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: When did the first farmers come to Britain?
questions.explaination: The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.

questions.question: Which of the following tells us about how people lived in England just after the Norman Conquest?
questions.explaination: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

questions.question: Which two of these forts were part of Hadrian’s wall?
questions.explaination: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people). Included in the wall were a number of forts. Parts of Hadrian’s Wall, including the forts of Housesteads and Vindolanda, can still be seen.

questions.question: Which tribe came to Britain from northern Europe after the Romans left in AD 410?
questions.explaination: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

questions.question: William I defeated king of Harold in which battle?
questions.explaination: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle.

questions.question: Skara Brae on Orkney is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe. Where is it located?
questions.explaination: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question: Which tribe came to Britain from northern Europe after the Romans left in AD 410?
questions.explaination: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

questions.question: From which modern country did William the Conqueror come from？
questions.explaination: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

questions.answer: He become the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: Where did the first farmers come from?
questions.explaination: The first farmers arrived in Britain 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.

questions.question: Who led the first invasion of Britain?
questions.explaination: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire. In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion.

questions.question: Under which king did the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England unite to defeat the Vikings?
questions.explaination: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

questions.question: Which was the last successful foreign invasion of England that took place in 1066?
questions.explaination: The Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England and led to many changes in government and social structures in England.

questions.question: Who was the tribal leader who fought against the Romans?
questions.explaination: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

questions.question: What battle is commemorated in the Bayeux Tapestry?
questions.explaination: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

questions.explaination: The first people to live in Britain were hunter-gatherers, in what we call the Stone Age.

questions.answer: The House of York;The House of Lancaster
questions.question: Which two houses fought in the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explaination: The Wars of the Roses were fought between the supporters of two families: the House of Lancaster and the House of York.

questions.question: What stories are associated with Geoffrey Chaucer?
questions.explaination: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

questions.question: Which two languages combined to become one English language?
questions.explaination: After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spoken Norman French and the peasants had continued to speak Anglo-Saxon. Gradually these two languages combined to become one English language. Some words in modern English – for example, ‘park’ and ‘beauty’ – are based on Norman French words. Others – for example, ‘apple’, ‘cow’ and ‘summer’ – are based on Anglo-Saxon words. In modern English there are often words with very similar meanings, one from French and one from Anglo-Saxon. ‘Demand’ (French) and ‘ask’ (Anglo-Saxon) are examples.

questions.question: Which Scottish king defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn?
questions.explaination: In Scotland, the English kings were less successful. In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.

questions.question: Which of the following poems is about a group of people going on a pilgrimage?
options: To be or not to be
questions.explaination: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

questions.answer: The first person in England to print books using a printing press

options: The first person to sail singlehanded around the world
The first person in England to print books using a printing press
questions.explaination: The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales. It was one of the first books to be printed by William Caxton, the first person in England to print books using a printing press.

questions.answer: After the War of Roses, Henry Tudor married with Elizabeth of York
questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
options: After the War of the Roses, Henry Tudor assigned his son Richard as King
After the War of Roses, Henry Tudor married with Elizabeth of York
questions.explaination: Wars of the Roses ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII. Henry then married King Richard’s niece, Elizabeth of York, and united the two families.

questions.question: What was the 'Black Death'?
questions.explaination: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

questions.question: The Canterbury Tales telling contest by a group of pilgrims as they travel together from ______ to ______?

The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

questions.explaination: The Magna Carta was created in 1215.

questions.question: Who was the first person in England to print books using a printing press?
questions.explaination: William Caxton was the first person in England to print books using a printing press.

questions.question: What is the name of the long war that English kings fought with France in the middle ages?
questions.explaination: English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).

questions.explaination: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

What was achieved with the Magna Carta?
options: Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing
questions.explaination: The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king’s power to collect taxes or to make or change laws.

questions.answer: Peasants who had a small area of their lord’s agricultural land
questions.question: During the Middle Ages, who were the serfs?
options: Noblemen who formed part of the king’s council of advisers
Peasants who had a small area of their lord’s agricultural land
New social classes who are the owners of large areas of land (later called the gentry)
Soldiers who fought at the Battle of Trafalgar
questions.explaination: The king gave land to his lords in return for help in war. Landowners had to send certain numbers of men to serve in the army. Some peasants had their own land but most were serfs.

questions.question: When did the English defeat the Spanish Armada?
questions.explaination: In 1588 the English defeated the Spanish Armada.

questions.question: Who was given the title of Lord Protector?
questions.explaination: Oliver Cromwell was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658.

questions.question: During the reign of Elizabeth I, a large fleet of ships was sent to England to conquer the country and to restore Catholicism, where did this fleet come from?

Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.answer: That every prisoner has a right to a court hearing
questions.question: What did the Habeas Corpus Act introduce?
options: Measures to improve the conditions of workers
That every prisoner has a right to a court hearing
Financial help for the unemployed, old-age pensions and free school meals
Increased the number of people with the right to vote
questions.explaination: The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today. Habeas corpus is Latin for ‘you must present the person in court’. The Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully. Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing.

questions.question: What was Isaac Newton known for?
questions.explaination: Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University. He became an important figure in the field. His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica(‘Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy’), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe. Newton also discovered that white light is made up of the colours of the rainbow.

questions.question: Where did the Spanish Armada come from?
questions.explaination: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question: What kind of church did Scotland establish in 1560?
questions.explaination: Scotland had also been strongly influenced by Protestant ideas. In 1560, the predominantly Protestant Scottish Parliament abolished the authority of the Pope in Scotland and Roman Catholic religious services became illegal. A Protestant Church of Scotland with an elected leadership was established but, unlike in England, this was not a state Church.

questions.question: Who was the architect that rebuilt Saint Paul’s cathedral after the Great Fire in 1666?
questions.explaination: During Charles II’s reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. Thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas. The following year, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul’s Cathedral. London was rebuilt with a new St Paul’s, which was designed by a famous architect, Sir Christopher Wren. Sir Christopher Wren helped develop a British version of the ornate styles popular in Europe in buildings such as the new St Paul’s Cathedral.

questions.question: The version of the Bible created by King James I is known as:
questions.explaination: One achievement of King James’ reign was a new translation of the Bible into English. This translation is known as the ‘King James Version’ or the ‘Authorised Version’. It was not the first English Bible but is a version which continues to be used in many Protestant churches today.

questions.question: Charles I believed in the ‘Divine Right of Kings’ so he tried:
options: To raise money for the Parliament
To rule with the approval of the Parliament
questions.explaination: James I and his son Charles I were less skilled politically. Both believed in the ‘Divine Right of Kings’: the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. They thought that the king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament. When Charles I inherited the thrones of England, Wales, Ireland and Scotland, he tried to rule in line with this principle. When he could not get Parliament to agree with his religious and foreign policies, he tried to rule without Parliament at all.

questions.question: How did Charles II manage to escape to Europe after his defeat in the Civil War?
questions.explaination: Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

questions.question: What religion did Elizabeth I follow?
questions.explaination: Queen Elizabeth I was a Protestant. She re-established the Church of England as the official Church in England. Everyone had to attend their local church and there were laws about the type of religious services and the prayers which could be said, but Elizabeth did not ask about people’s real beliefs. She succeeded in finding a balance between the views of Catholics and the more extreme Protestants.

questions.question: James I was King of which country before becoming King of England?
questions.explaination: Elizabeth I never married and so had no children of her own to inherit her throne. When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland. He became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland but Scotland remained a separate country.

questions.question: Which country sent a fleet of ships to England in 1588?
questions.explaination: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question: When was England ruled by a republic and not by a monarch?
options: When the Carta Magna restricted the king’s power
When Elizabeth I died without any successor
When kind Harold died after the Battle of Hastings
questions.explaination: By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed. England declared itself a republic, called the Commonwealth. It no longer had a monarch.

questions.question: Who fought in the English Civil war of 1642?
options: The House of York and the House of Lancaster
The House of Fraser and the House of Stuart
questions.explaination: Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

questions.question: What was the religion of the Puritans?
questions.explaination: Many in Parliament were Puritans, a group of Protestants who advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship.

questions.question: Who came from the Netherlands to become the British monarch?
questions.explaination: In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.

questions.question: Under which name was the movement of opinion against the authority of the Pope during the times of Henry VIII known?
questions.explaination: At the same time the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church. The Protestants formed their own churches.

questions.question: What did Isaac Newton discover?
questions.explaination: Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University. His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica(‘Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy’), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe.

questions.question: Who invaded Ireland with the help of a French army in 1690?
questions.explaination: James II wanted to regain the throne and invaded Ireland with the help of a French army. William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today.

questions.question: What is the title of Shakespeare's best known play?
questions.explaination: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was a playwright and actor and wrote many poems and plays. His most famous plays include A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Hamlet, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet.

questions.question: Who was asked by Protestants to invade England and replaced James II as King?
questions.explaination: William of Orange was asked by important Protestants in England to invade England and proclaim himself king.

questions.question: Elizabeth I never married and so had no children of her own to inherit her throne. From which country does King James I was King before becoming King of England?
questions.explaination: Elizabeth I never married and so had no children of her own to inherit her throne. When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland. He became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland but Scotland remained a separate country.

questions.question: Which of the following plays was written by William Shakespeare?
questions.explaination: He was a playwright and actor and wrote many poems and plays. His most famous plays include A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Hamlet, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet.

questions.question: Why did Henry VIII establish the church of England?
options: To establish a unique religion in England
To have control over religious people
questions.explaination: To divorce his first wife, Henry needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship

questions.question: During the reign of Charles II parts of London were destroyed, what was the cause of this destruction?
questions.explaination: During Charles II’s reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. Thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas. The following year, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul’s Cathedral.

questions.question: Who supported King Charles I during the Civil War?
questions.explaination: Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

questions.question: Where was Anne Boleyn, the wife of Henry VIII, executed?
questions.explaination: Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth. Anne was unpopular in the country and was accused of taking lovers. She was executed at the Tower of London.

questions.question: What king was defeated by Oliver Cromwell during the Civil War and hid in an oak tree before escaping to Europe?
questions.explaination: Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

questions.question: Who was the father of Queen Elizabeth I?
questions.explaination: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant. Edward died at the age of 15 after ruling for just over six years, and his half-sister Mary became queen. Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.

questions.answer: Mary Stuart (‘Mary, Queen of Scots’) was a Catholic
questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE:
options: Mary Stuart (‘Mary, Queen of Scots’) was a Protestant
Mary Stuart (‘Mary, Queen of Scots’) was a Catholic
questions.explaination: Mary Stuart (‘Mary, Queen of Scots’) was a Catholic.

questions.question: William of Orange was asked by Protestants to invade England and proclaim himself king. But, when William reached England, there was no resistance and he took over the throne. This event was later Known as:
questions.explaination: James II’s elder daughter, Mary, was married to her cousin William of Orange, the Protestant ruler of the Netherlands. In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III in England, Wales and Ireland, and William II of Scotland. This event was later called the ‘Glorious Revolution’.

questions.question: Which king was executed in 1649?
questions.explaination: The king’s army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.

questions.question: Where was William Shakespeare born?
questions.explaination: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

questions.question: Who was reigning in England when English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America?
questions.explaination: In Elizabeth I’s time, English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America. This colonisation, particularly by people who disagreed with the religious views of the next two kings, greatly increased in the next century.

questions.question: Who established the Church of England?
questions.explaination: To divorce his first wife, Henry needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

questions.answer: Elizabeth I was a Protestant and she succeeded in finding a balance between the views of the Catholics and the more extreme Protestants.
questions.question: Which of the following statements is true:
options: Elizabeth I was a Protestant and she succeeded in finding a balance between the views of the Catholics and the more extreme Protestants.
Elizabeth I was a Catholic and she succeeded in finding a balance between the views of the Catholics and the more extreme Protestants.
questions.explaination: Queen Elizabeth I was a Protestant. She re-established the Church of England as the official Church in England. Everyone had to attend their local church and there were laws about the type of religious services and the prayers which could be said, but Elizabeth did not ask about people’s real beliefs. She succeeded in finding a balance between the views of Catholics and the more extreme Protestants.

questions.question: Which Scottish clan was killed for not taking the oath?
questions.explaination: All Scottish clans were required formally to accept William as king by taking an oath. The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed.

questions.answer: The Battle of Marston Moor;The Battle of Naseby
questions.question: Which two of the following are Civil War Battles?
questions.explaination: The king’s army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army.

questions.question: What is the name of the movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas of the Catholic Church that took place during the reign of Henry VIII?
questions.explaination: At the same time the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.

questions.question: What happened to ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’ after she spent 20 years in prison?
questions.explaination: Mary was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.

questions.question: Who did the English defeat in 1588?
questions.explaination: In 1588, the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question: Who was born in Stratford-upon-Avon?
questions.explaination: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

questions.question: What movement challenged the authority of the Pope?
questions.explaination: At the same time the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.

questions.question: When were men and women given the right to vote at the age of 21?
questions.explaination: In 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.question: The Bill of Rights of 1689 confirmed the right to vote for all adult men.
questions.explaination: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power.

questions.answer: In recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War
questions.question: Why were women given the right to vote?
options: In recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the Civil War
In recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the Crimean War
In recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War
In recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the Second World War
questions.explaination: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War.

questions.question: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolution marked the beginning of the ______.
questions.explaination: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolution are the beginning of what is called ‘constitutional monarchy’. The monarch remained very important but was no longer able to insist on particular policies or actions if Parliament did not agree.

questions.answer: The right for women to vote
questions.question: What did Emmeline Pankhurst fight for?
options: Prohibition of slavery and forced labour
The right for women to vote
The right to liberty and security
questions.explaination: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women’s Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women’s Social and Political Union (WSPU). This was the first group whose members were called ‘suffragettes’. The group used civil disobedience as part of their protest to gain the vote for women.

questions.answer: A period when new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed
questions.question: What is the Enlightenment?
options: A period of total peace in England
A period when England became the largest empire the world had ever seen
A period when new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed
A period of economic recovery after the Second World War
questions.explaination: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’.

questions.question: Who was Emmeline Pankhurst?
questions.explaination: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women’s Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women’s Social and Political Union (WSPU). This was the first group whose members were called ‘suffragettes’. The group used civil disobedience as part of their protest to gain the vote for women.

questions.question: Who did Britain fight against in the Crimean War?
questions.explaination: From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War. It was the first war to be extensively covered by the media through news stories and photographs.

questions.question: Who was in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar?
questions.explaination: Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

questions.question: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came to England, which country did they come from?
questions.explaination: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion. Many were educated and skilled and worked as scientists, in banking, or in weaving or other crafts.

questions.answer: The flag of the United Kingdom
questions.question: What is the Union Jack?
options: The shield used by British Knights
The flag of the United Kingdom
The flag of the European Union
questions.explaination: One symbol of the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland was a new version of the official flag, the Union Flag. This is often called the Union Jack. The flag combined crosses associated with England, Scotland and Ireland. It is still used today as the official flag of the UK.

questions.question: During the rebellion of the clans in Scotland, Bonnie Prince Charlie was supported by clansmen from which Scottish region?
questions.explaination: Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army.

questions.question: Against which country did Britain fight at the Battle of Waterloo?
questions.explaination: The British army also fought against the French. In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

questions.question: Who was William Wilberforce?
questions.explaination: William Wilberforce, an evangelical Christian and a member of Parliament, also played an important part in changing the law. Along with other abolitionists (people who supported the abolition of slavery), he succeeded in turning public opinion against the slave trade.

questions.question: Who was the first British Prime Minister?
questions.explaination: The most important minister in Parliament became known as the Prime Minister. The first man to be called this was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

questions.question: During the Enlightenment, Adam Smith developed ideas about:
questions.explaination: Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today. David Hume’s ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers. Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt’s work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: Who died at the Battle of Trafalgar?
questions.explaination: Napoleon, who became Emperor of France, continued the war. Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

questions.question: Who mapped the coast of Australia?
questions.explaination: Captain James Cook mapped the coast of Australia and a few colonies were established there.

questions.question: What was the first war to be extensively covered by the media?
questions.explaination: From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War. It was the first war to be extensively covered by the media through news stories and photographs.

questions.answer: To link the factories to towns and cities and to the ports
questions.question: Why were canals built during the Industrial Revolution?
options: To make space for the large fleet of British ships
To link the factories to towns and cities and to the ports
To increase the amount of water in towns and cities
To increase the number of water mills in the UK
questions.explaination: Better transport links were needed to transport raw materials and manufactured goods. Canals were built to link the factories to towns and cities and to the ports, particularly in the new industrial areas in the middle and north of England.

questions.question: Which invention led to the development of Britain during the Industrial Revolution?
questions.explaination: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt’s work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: In 1776, which British colonies declared their independence because they demanded that there should be ‘no taxation without representation’.
questions.explaination: By the 1760s, there were substantial British colonies in North America. The colonies were wealthy and largely in control of their own affairs. Many of the colonist families had originally gone to North America in order to have religious freedom. They were well educated and interested in ideas of liberty. The British government wanted to tax the colonies. The colonists saw this as an attack on their freedom and said there should be ‘no taxation without representation’ in the British Parliament.

questions.question: What song is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year?
questions.explaination: The song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

questions.question: What is the name of Irish people who favoured complete independence from the UK in the 19th century?
questions.explaination: The Irish Nationalist movement had grown strongly through the 19th century. Some, such as the Fenians, favoured complete independence.

questions.question: When did the Emancipation Act abolish slavery throughout the British Empire?
questions.explaination: In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

questions.answer: The construction of the Great Western Railway.
questions.question: Isambard Kingdom Brunel was responsible for:
options: The invention of the steam engine.
The construction of the Tower of London.
The construction of the Great Western Railway.
questions.explaination: Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806–59) was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships. He was responsible for constructing the Great Western Railway, which was the first major railway built in Britain.

questions.question: During the 18th century the Enlightenment, which aspect was David Hume's contribution?
questions.explaination: David Hume’s ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers.

questions.question: Who was Sake Dean Mahomet?
questions.explaination: Sake Dean Mahomet (1759–1851) was born in 1759 and grew up in the Bengal region of India. In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain. Mahomet and his wife also introduced ‘shampooing’, the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.

questions.answer: A new law limited the number of hours women and children could work
questions.question: How was the working condition improved for women and children in 1847?
options: A new law limited the number of hours women and children could work
questions.explaination: Working conditions in factories gradually became better. In 1847, the number of hours that women and children could work was limited by law to 10 hours per day. Better housing began to be built for workers.

questions.question: During 18 Century, an important role appeared in the parliament?
questions.explaination: The most important minister in Parliament became known as the Prime Minister. The first man to be called this was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

questions.question: During 1840s, which crop was affected by a disease causing Ireland suffered from famine?
questions.explaination: In the middle of the century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation.

questions.question: Before the 18th century, what was the biggest source of employment?
questions.explaination: Before the 18th century, agriculture was the biggest source of employment in Britain. There were many cottage industries, where people worked from home to produce goods such as cloth and lace. The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries. Manufacturing jobs became the main source of employment in Britain.

questions.question: What was Isambard Kingdom Brunel responsible for?
questions.explaination: Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806–59) was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships. He was responsible for constructing the Great Western Railway, which was the first major railway built in Britain.

questions.question: What is the name, after the Glorious Revolution, the monarch was no longer able to insist on particular policies or actions if parliamentary did not agree.
questions.explaination: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolution are the beginning of what is called ‘constitutional monarchy’. The monarch remained very important but was no longer able to insist on particular policies or actions if Parliament did not agree.

questions.question: During 18 Century, an important post appeared in the parliament, Sir Robert Walpole taken that post.
questions.explaination: The most important minister in Parliament became known as the Prime Minister. The first man to be called this was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

questions.question: Women over the age of 30 were given the right to vote as a result of their contribution towards the war effort. Which war was that?
questions.explaination: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War.

questions.question: Who was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised and army in 1745?
questions.explaination: In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I’s son, George II. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised and army.

questions.answer: The British government wanted to tax them
questions.question: What led the American colonies to want their independence from Britain?
options: They were running out of resources
The British government wanted to control their borders
There were not enough jobs for the local people
The British government wanted to tax them
questions.explaination: The British government wanted to tax the colonies. The colonists saw this as an attack on their freedom and said there should be ‘no taxation without representation’ in the British Parliament.

questions.question: Who was the leader of the suffragettes, the group that campaigned for women’s rights to vote?
questions.explaination: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women’s Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women’s Social and Political Union (WSPU). This was the first group whose members were called ‘suffragettes’.

questions.question: What was the last battle between Great Britain and France?
questions.explaination: The British army also fought against the French. In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

questions.question: When did women get the right to vote at the same age as men?
questions.explaination: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21.

questions.question: What is the name of the period when new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed?
questions.explaination: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’.

questions.question: In which battle did Admiral Nelson die?
questions.explaination: Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

questions.question: In which country of the British Empire did the Boer War (1899-1902) take place?
questions.explaination: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent. The British went to war in South Africa with settlers from the Netherlands called the Boers.

questions.question: The Bill of Rights in 1689 gave women the right to vote.
questions.explaination: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power.

questions.question: What was the biggest source of employment during the 18th century?
questions.explaination: Before the 18th century, agriculture was the biggest source of employment in Britain. There were many cottage industries, where people worked from home to produce goods such as cloth and lace. The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries. Manufacturing jobs became the main source of employment in Britain.

questions.question: In 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.
What is the name of the process by which many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as ‘crofts’) to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle?
questions.explaination: A process began which became known as the ‘Highland Clearances’. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as ‘crofts’) to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle.

questions.question: What was the name of the activist group who fought for the women’s right to vote?
questions.explaination: Emmeline Pankhurst set up the Women’s Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women’s Social and Political Union (WSPU). This was the first group whose members were called ‘suffragettes’. The group used civil disobedience as part of their protest to gain the vote for women.

questions.question: What year were women given the right to vote?
questions.explaination: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War. Shortly before Emmeline’s death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.question: The last battle between Britain and France was the battle of Trafalgar.
questions.explaination: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

questions.answer: Women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.
questions.question: Why is 1928 an important year in women’s voting history?
options: Women were given the right to vote at the age of 18, the same as men.
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 25.
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 30.
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.
questions.explaination: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

questions.question: Which of the following wars took place between 1899 and 1902 in South Africa?
questions.explaination: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent. The British went to war in South Africa with settlers from the Netherlands called the Boers.

questions.answer: Abolishing a number of taxes on imported goods
questions.question: How did the Government promote policies of free trade during the Victorian Age?
options: Preventing the importation of cheap raw materials
Preventing the importation of cheap grain
Abolishing a number of taxes on imported goods
Abolishing the exportation of local produce
questions.explaination: Britain continued to be a great trading nation. The government began to promote policies of free trade, abolishing a number of taxes on imported goods.

questions.answer: A British officer in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar against the Spanish fleet
questions.question: Who was Admiral Nelson?
options: A British general who established the authority of the English Parliament
A British officer in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar against the Spanish fleet
A British officer in charge of the British army at the Battle of Waterloo
One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans
questions.explaination: Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

questions.question: Which invention lead to the rapid development of the industry in Britain during the 18th and 19th centuries?
questions.explaination: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries. Britain was the first country to industrialise on a large scale. It happened because of the development of machinery and the use of steam power.

questions.question: What building was constructed in Hyde Park to hold the Great Exhibition of 1851?
questions.explaination: In 1851, the Great Exhibition opened in Hyde Park in the Crystal Palace, a huge building made of steel and glass.

questions.question: Who was Florence Nightingale?
questions.explaination: Florence Nightingale was born in Italy to English parents. At the age of 31, she trained as a nurse in Germany.

questions.question: When did the WWI come to an end?
questions.explaination: On 28 June 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was assassinated. This set off a chain of events leading to the First World War (1914–18).

questions.question: Which of the following was a crucial aerial battle fought between Germany and Britain during WWII?
questions.explaination: Hitler wanted to invade Britain, but before sending in troops, Germany needed to control the air. The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called ‘the Battle of Britain’, in the summer of 1940.

questions.answer: The evacuation of Allied soldiers from France during World War II
questions.question: What is known as the “Dunkirk spirit”?
options: When new social classes appeared after the Black Death
The evacuation of Allied soldiers from France during World War II
When the German air force bombed London and other British cities at night-time
The period when many refugees called Huguenots came from France
questions.explaination: As France fell, the British decided to evacuate British and French soldiers from France in a huge naval operation. Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. Although many lives and a lot of equipment were lost, the evacuation was a success and meant that Britain was better able to continue the fight against the Germans. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase ‘the Dunkirk spirit’.

questions.question: Which armed force was used in the Battle of Britain?
questions.explaination: Hitler wanted to invade Britain, but before sending in troops, Germany needed to control the air. The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called ‘the Battle of Britain’, in the summer of 1940. The most important planes used by the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain were the Spitfire and the Hurricane – which were designed and built in Britain.

questions.question: When did the First World War end?
questions.explaination: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11th November 1918 with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.question: Who led a team of scientists to ‘split the atom’ for the first time?
questions.explaination: Scientists led by Ernest Rutherford, working at Manchester and then Cambridge University, were the first to ‘split the atom’ and took part in the Manhattan Project in the United States, which developed the atomic bomb.

questions.question: What is the name used to describe the bombing campaign during WWII when Germany bombed multiple UK cities？
questions.explaination: The German air force was able to continue bombing London and other British cities at night-time. This was called the Blitz.

questions.question: When did Ireland become a republic?
questions.explaination: Ireland became a republic in 1949.

questions.question: Who became Prime Minister and was an inspirational leader to the British people during WWII?
questions.explaination: Churchill was the son of a politician and, before becoming a Conservative MP in 1900, was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister. He refused to surrender to the Nazis and was an inspirational leader to the British people in a time of great hardship.

questions.question: During the Great Depression in the 1930s which industry was badly affected?
questions.explaination: The effects of the depression of the 1930s were felt differently in different parts of the UK. The traditional heavy industries such as shipbuilding were badly affected but new industries – including the automobile and aviation industries – developed.

questions.question: Who was voted the greatest Briton of all time in 2002?
questions.explaination: Winston Churchill was an MP until he stood down at the 1964 General Election. Following his death in 1965, he was given a state funeral. He remains a much-admired figure to this day, and in 2002 was voted the greatest Briton of all time by the public.

questions.question: When did Germany invade Poland?
questions.explaination: when Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France declared war in order to stop his aggression.

questions.question: What sort of battle was the ‘Battle of Britain’, fought between Germany and Britain in the summer of 1940?
questions.explaination: Hitler wanted to invade Britain, but before sending in troops, Germany needed to control the air. The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called ‘the Battle of Britain’, in the summer of 1940.

questions.answer: Due to the outbreak of the First World War
questions.question: In 1913, the British government promised ‘Home Rule’ for Ireland, why were changes in Ireland delayed until 1921?
options: Due to the outbreak of the Black Death
Due to the outbreak of the First World War
Due to the outbreak of the Second World War
Because there was not a king on the British throne
questions.explaination: In 1913, the British government promised ‘Home Rule’ for Ireland. The proposal was to have a self-governing Ireland with its own parliament but still part of the UK. A Home Rule Bill was introduced in Parliament. It was opposed by the Protestants in the north of Ireland, who threatened to resist Home Rule by force. The outbreak of the First World War led the British government to postpone any changes in Ireland.

questions.question: The assassination of the Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914 led to which of the following wars?
questions.explaination: On 28 June 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was assassinated. This set off a chain of events leading to the First World War (1914–18)

questions.question: World War II started as a result of Germany invading which country?
questions.explaination: When Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France declared war in order to stop his aggression.

questions.question: Who was the first female Prime Minister of the UK?
questions.explaination: Margaret Thatcher was the first woman Prime Minister of the UK.

questions.question: What did Sir Frank Whittle invent in the 1930s?
questions.explaination: The jet engine was developed in Britain in the 1930s by Sir Frank Whittle.

questions.answer: She was the first woman Prime Minister of the UK
questions.question: What was Margaret Thatcher famous for?
options: She was the founder of modern nursing
She set up the women’s Franchise League
She fought for the right to vote for women
She was the first woman Prime Minister of the UK
questions.explaination: Margaret Thatcher, Britain’s first woman Prime Minister, led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990.

questions.answer: A growth in British fashion and pop music
questions.question: What is the period of the 1960s known for?
options: A growth in British fashion and pop music
Working conditions in factories gradually became better.
It was a time when Britain increased in power and influence abroad.
questions.explaination: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as ‘the Swinging Sixties’. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music.

questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
questions.explaination: The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955–), is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

questions.question: Who was elected as British Prime Minister in 1945?
questions.explaination: In 1945 the British people elected a Labour government. The new Prime Minister was Clement Atlee, who promised to introduce the welfare state outlined in the Beveridge Report.

questions.question: Which of the following countries helped Britain to develop the Concorde?
questions.explaination: The 1960s was also a time of technological progress. Britain and France developed the world’s only supersonic commercial airliner, Concorde.

questions.question: What medal did Mary Peters win in the 1972 Olympics?
questions.explaination: Mary Peters (1939–) born in Manchester, Mary Peters moved to Northern Ireland as a child. She was a talented athlete who won an Olympic gold medal in the pentathlon in 1972.

questions.question: What was invented by Alan Turing in the 1930s?
questions.explaination: A Turing machine is a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing (1912–54), a British mathematician, in the 1930s.

questions.question: Which two British pop music groups were famous during the Swinging Sixties?
questions.explaination: Two well-known pop music groups at the time were The Beatles and The Rolling Stones.

questions.question: Who was the British scientist who co-discovered the structure of the DNA molecule in the 1950s?
questions.explaination: The structure of the DNA molecule was discovered in 1953 through work at British universities in London and Cambridge. Francis Crick (1916–2004), one of those awarded the Nobel Prize for this discovery, was British.

questions.question: Who was the leader of the Labour Party who introduced a Scottish Parliament and a Welsh Assembly?

questions.explaination: Richard Austen Butler (later Lord Butler) was born in 1902. He became a Conservative MP in 1923 and held several positions before becoming responsible for education in 1941. Vaisakhi (also spelled Baisakhi) is a Sikh festival which celebrates the founding of the Sikh community known as the Khalsa.

questions.question: What was Edward Elgar famous for?

questions.answer: An eight-week summer season of daily orchestral classical music concerts
questions.question: What is “the Proms”?
options: Light-hearted plays with music and comedy
An annual cultural festival which includes music, dance, art and original performances largely in Welsh
An eight-week summer season of daily orchestral classical music concerts
An annual event that gives awards in a range of categories, such as best British group and best British solo artist
questions.explaination: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of orchestral classical music that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London. It has been organised by the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) since 1927. The Last Night of the Proms is the most well-known concert and (along with others in the series) is broadcast on television.

questions.question: Where is Theatreland?

questions.question: What is the name of the War Memorial located in Whitehall?

After the First World War, he was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall. The Cenotaph is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the Queen, politicians and foreign ambassadors.

questions.explaination: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park covers 720 square miles (1,865 square kilometres) in the west of Scotland. Loch Lomond is the largest expanse of fresh water in mainland Britain and probably the best- known part of the park.

questions.question: Which is the largest National Park in England?
options: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park
questions.explaination: The Lake District is England’s largest national park. It covers 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres).

questions.question: Where do Beefeaters serve as tour guides?
questions.explaination: The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066. Tours are given by the Yeoman Warders, also known as Beefeaters, who tell visitors about the building’s history.

questions.question: Where is the Giant’s Causeway located?
questions.explaination: Located on the north-east coast of Northern Ireland, the Giant’s Causeway is a land formation of columns made from volcanic lava. It was formed about 50 million years ago. There are many legends about the Causeway and how it was formed.

questions.question: What is landmark which located in Cornwall, in the south west of England?
options: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park
questions.explaination: The Eden Project is located in Cornwall, in the south west of England. Its biomes, which are like giant greenhouses, house plants from all over the world.

questions.question: Which historical monument did William the Conqueror build?
questions.explaination: The White Tower in the Tower of London is an example of a Norman castle keep, built on the orders of William the Conqueror.

questions.question: Where are the Crown Jewels kept?
questions.explaination: The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066. Tours are given by the Yeoman Warders, also known as Beefeaters, who tell visitors about the building’s history. People can also see the Crown Jewels there.

questions.question: What is the name of the tour guides that tell visitors stories about the Tower of London’s history?
questions.explaination: The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066. Tours are given by the Yeoman Warders, also known as Beefeaters, who tell visitors about the building’s history.

questions.question: Where is Snowdonia located?
questions.explaination: Snowdonia is a national park in North Wales.

questions.question: Lake District is the largest national park of England.
questions.explaination: The Lake District is England’s largest national park. It covers 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres).

questions.question: What charity works to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK?
questions.explaination: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK.

questions.question: Where is the Eden Project located?
questions.explaination: The Eden Project is located in Cornwall, in the south west of England. Its biomes, which are like giant greenhouses, house plants from all over the world.

questions.question: There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. What are national parks?
options: Land formations of columns made from volcanic lava
questions.explaination: There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

questions.question: What UK landmark was voted as Britain’s favourite view in 2007?
questions.explaination: The Lake District is England’s largest national park. It covers 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres). It is famous for its lakes and mountains and is very popular with climbers, walkers and sailors. The biggest stretch of water is Windermere. In 2007, television viewers voted Wastwater as Britain’s favourite view.

questions.question: How many national parks are there in England, Wales and Scotland?
questions.explaination: There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

questions.question: Where is the Lake District National Park located?
questions.explaination: The Lake District is England’s largest national park. It covers 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres). It is famous for its lakes and mountains and is very popular with climbers, walkers and sailors.

questions.question: Who chairs the debates at the House of Commons?
questions.explaination: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired by the Speaker.

questions.question: Does Britain have a written constitution?
questions.explaination: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten’. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government. Our most important institutions have developed over hundreds of years. Some people believe that there should be a single document, but others believe an unwritten constitution allows for more flexibility and better government.

questions.question: MPs can only be contacted at their office in the House of Commons.
questions.explaination: You can contact MPs by letter or telephone at their constituency Office, or at their Office in the House of Commons. In addition, many MPs, Assembly members, MSPs and MEPs hold regular local ‘surgeries’, where constituents can go in person to talk about issues that are of concern to them. These surgeries are often advertised in the local newspaper.

questions.question: Who appoints life peers in the House of Lords?
questions.explaination: Since 1958, the Prime Minister has had the power to nominate peers just for their own lifetime. These are called life peers. Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister. They also include people nominated by the leaders of the other main political parties or by an independent Appointments Commission for non-party peers.

questions.question: The members of the House of Lords, known as peers, are elected by the people.
questions.explaination: Members of the House of Lords, known as peers, are not elected by the people and do not represent a constituency.

questions.answer: Represent the constituency;Helping to make new law
questions.question: Which two of below are the responsibility of MP?
options: Nominate peers in the House of Lord
questions.explaination:
Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs form the House of Commons. MPs have a number of different responsibilities. They:
-represent everyone in their constituency
-help to create new laws
-scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing
-debate important national issues.

questions.question: A responsibility of the MPs is to represent everyone in their _______.
questions.explaination: Each MP represents a parliamentary constituency, which is a small area of the country.

questions.question: Under constitutional monarchy, the king or the queen has the right to:
options: insist on particular policies or actions if Parliament did not agree
questions.explaination: The UK has a constitutional monarchy. This means that the king or queen does not rule the country but appoints the government, which the people have chosen in a democratic election. The monarch remained very important but was no longer able to insist on particular policies or actions if Parliament did not agree.

questions.question: Which is not a Constituency organizations?
questions.explaination: Several different parts of government. The main ones are: the monarchy,Parliament (the House of Commons and the House of Lords),the Prime Minister,the cabinet,the judiciary (courts),the police,the civil service,local government.

questions.answer: The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party.
questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
options: The Speaker can represent a political party.
The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party.
questions.explaination: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired by the Speaker. This person is the chief Officer of the House of Commons. The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents’ problems like any other MP. The Speaker is chosen by other MPs in a secret ballot.

questions.question: The Speaker of the House of Commons _____.
options: is not part of the parliament
is chosen by everyone in the UK in a secret ballot
questions.explaination: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired by the Speaker.

questions.question: How often are general elections held in the UK?
questions.explaination: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

questions.answer: The House of Lords;House of Commons
questions.question: Which two houses form the UK Parliament?
questions.explaination: The UK Parliament is formed of the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

questions.question: What sort of election takes place when a member of the Parliament (MP) dies or resigns?
questions.explaination: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a byelection, in his or her constituency.

questions.question: MPs can only be contacted by post.
questions.explaination: You can contact MPs by letter or telephone at their constituency Office, or at their Office in the House of Commons. In addition, many MPs, Assembly members, MSPs and MEPs hold regular local ‘surgeries’, where constituents can go in person to talk about issues that are of concern to them. These surgeries are often advertised in the local newspaper.

questions.question: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy.
questions.explaination: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy. The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies. Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs form the House of Commons.

questions.question: How many members does the Welsh government have?
questions.explaination: The Welsh government and National Assembly for Wales are based in Cardiff, the capital city of Wales. The National Assembly has 60 Assembly members (AMs) and elections are held every four years using a form of proportional representation.

questions.question: By law, radio and television coverage of the political parties must be balanced and so equal time has to be given to rival viewpoints.
The Northern Ireland Assembly cannot make decisions on which two of the following issues?
questions.explaination: Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control. However, many other public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations. The Northern Ireland Assembly can make decisions on issues such as:education,agriculture,the environment,health,social services.

questions.question: How many members does the Northern Ireland Assembly have?
questions.explaination: The Northern Ireland Assembly was established soon after the Belfast Agreement (or Good Friday Agreement) in 1998. There is a power-sharing agreement which distributes ministerial Offices amongst the main parties. The Assembly has 90 elected members, known as MLAs (members of the Legislative Assembly). They are elected with a form of proportional representation.

questions.question: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by government appointed officials.
questions.explaination: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by democratically elected councils, often called ‘local authorities’. Some areas have both district and county councils, which have different functions. Most large towns and cities have a single local authority.

questions.answer: They are chosen on merit and are politically neutral
questions.question: How are civil servants appointed and what political party do they belong to?
options: They are chosen randomly and form part of the Conservative party
They are chosen randomly and are politically neutral
They are chosen on merit and are politically neutral
They are chosen on merit and form part of the Liberal Democrats party
questions.explaination: Civil servants support the government in developing and implementing its policies. They also deliver public services. Civil servants are accountable to ministers. They are chosen on merit and are politically neutral – they are not political appointees.

questions.question: In the UK, you have to be 21 years old to be able to vote in a general election.
questions.explaination: The present voting age of 18 was set in 1969 and (with a few exceptions) all UK-born and naturalised adult citizens have the right to vote.

questions.answer: By a system of proportional representation
questions.question: How are the members of the Northern Ireland Parliament elected?
options: Using the first past the post system
By a system of proportional representation
Using a system of ranked voting
questions.explaination: The Northern Ireland Assembly was established soon after the Belfast Agreement (or Good Friday Agreement) in 1998. The Assembly has 90 elected members, known as MLAs (members of the Legislative Assembly). They are elected with a form of proportional representation.

questions.question: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports known as:
questions.explaination: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard. Written reports can be found in large libraries and at www.parliament.uk. Most people get information about political issues and events from newspapers (often called ‘the press’), television, radio and the internet.

questions.question: Are civil servants appointed by the government?
questions.explaination: Civil servants support the government in developing and implementing its policies. They also deliver public services. Civil servants are accountable to ministers. They are chosen on merit and are politically neutral – they are not political appointees.

questions.question: Who is responsible for crime, policing and immigration?
questions.explaination:
Home Secretary – responsible for crime, policing and immigration
Foreign Secretary – responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries
Chancellor of the Exchequer – responsible for the economy
other ministers (called ‘Secretaries of State’) responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

questions.question: National Assembly for Wales cannot pass any laws without the agreement of the UK Parliament.
questions.explaination: Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control. questions.question: Is the Scottish parliament located in Glasgow?
questions.explaination: The Scottish Parliament was formed in 1999. It sits in Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland.

questions.question: The role of which group of ministers is to challenge the ruling government and offer alternate policies
questions.explaination: They form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

questions.question: What are the MPs who do not represent any of the main political parties called?
questions.explaination: There are a few MPs who do not represent any of the main political parties. They are called ‘independents’ and usually represent an issue important to their constituency.

questions.question: In what areas of the Northern Ireland Assembly can make decisions?
questions.explaination: Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control. questions.question: What is the Home Secretary responsible for?
